Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Exploring convergence within pitcher plant microcosms
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the factors driving community formation within a host or habitat has implications for global climate change, human health, and microbial ecology. As host species shift location, can other symbionts substitute for those from the original habitat? Pitcher plants have modified leaves that collect water and microbes, and trap insects that are digested for nutrients. These pitchers can be thought of as plant analogs to the human gut, and studying how their microbial communities form, interact with each other, and assist with host digestion could inform our understanding of our own gut inhabitants. The project will involve training opportunities for American and Malaysian students, and will foster cooperation and networking with scientists in Malaysian Borneo. The researchers will work collaboratively to create educational exhibits for the Malaysian research center, and the complex ecology of pitcher plants will be shared with children and adults through a Harvard Museum of Natural History family program.

Convergence of form and function is common in all domains of life, because similar selective forces in geographically distant locations shape evolutionary change. Pitchers of carnivorous plants are exquisite examples of convergent evolution: pitcher plant morphology and function has evolved separately in three distant plant lineages in different biogeographic regions. This study investigates whether the organisms associated with pitchers show similar patterns of convergence in the nature of their ecological interactions. It will compare community pattern and function across four different kingdoms, within convergent hosts. With two genera of pitcher plants, Sarracenia in North America and Nepenthes in Southeast Asia, the microbial community composition across different pitcher plant species and collecting sites will be determined by DNA sequencing of the fungal, bacterial, and protist inhabitants. The ability of pitcher plant insects and microbes to colonize a convergently evolved host will be investigated by placing Nepenthes plants in a Sarracenia habitat, along with artificial controls, to see if and how insects and microbes colonize unfamiliar hosts. A laboratory experiment will compare native and convergently evolved microbial communities in facilitating the nutrient-limited pitcher plants in nitrogen uptake from prey. Finally, to determine if community patterns of inhabitants are similar across convergent hosts the similarity of taxa, community patterns, and factors structuring communities in Sarracenia and Nepenthes insect and microbial associates will be tested using metagenomic analyses to examine community functional capacity within convergent pitcher plant hosts by statistical and phylogenetic analyses, and with null models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A major goal of this project was to better understand factors driving the formation of ecological communities within a particular host or habitat. Communities of organisms and their abiotic environments make up ecosystems, which are the essential components of our planet. Carnivorous pitcher plants allow us to study ecosystems, on a smaller scale. Pitchers are cup-shaped, modified leaves that hold rainwater and plant enzymes. They trap and digest insects to access limiting nutrients, but also house entire ecosystems of living aquatic insects, fungi, protozoa and bacteria. Pitcher plants have evolved independently in different parts of the world, providing the opportunity to investigate the assembly of communities within similar, but unrelated, host habitats.

NSF Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant funding supported Leonora Bittleston in finishing her dissertation research: “Convergent interactions among pitcher plant microcosms in North America and Southeast Asia.” She developed and published a concept called “convergent interactions,” defined as the independent emergence of multispecies interactions with similar physiological or ecological functions. Convergent interactions can help biologists recognize the ecological roles of undescribed species, predict the functions of species associated with another organisms, or infer selective pressures acting in one system based on data from a different system.

With regard to pitcher plant microcosms, Bittleston characterized the communities of microbes and insects living in eight species of Southeast Asian pitcher plants, and six species of North American pitcher plants. She found that pitchers house fewer species than the habitats directly surrounding them, and that the numbers of species were similar in pitchers from opposite sides of the world. Although different species live in pitchers from Southeast Asia or North America, pitchers tended to house species from related groups of organisms, suggesting that they select similar organisms from the available environmental pool. The acidity of the fluid and the shape of the pitcher both strongly influenced which organisms colonized pitchers. In terms of function, pitcher plant communities tended to have more genes for fatty acid degradation than those of other habitats, such as lakes or soil, and fewer genes for degradation of simple sugars. When pitchers from Southeast Asia were relocated to a North American habitat, the same organisms that live in the local pitcher plants colonized them. The pitcher shape, the way it holds water, and the way it captures prey all likely contribute to the composition of the communities within.

The research resulted in a dissertation, three peer-reviewed publications, and a book chapter, with another manuscript still in progress. During the course of this project, Bittleston trained and mentored two undergraduate students who completed senior theses on related topics. She led research expeditions in Malaysian Borneo, Singapore, the U.S. Gulf Coast and Australia, and trained Malaysian and American students in fieldwork techniques. At the University of Malaysia, Sabah, Bittleston designed and led two workshops in DNA extraction and building evolutionary trees. To disseminate the results with both the scientific community and the public, Bittleston presented at multiple conferences, including the Ecological Society of America and the International Society for Microbial Ecology, and gave public lectures through the Science in the News organization and the Harvard Horizons program. She also organized a carnivorous plants exhibit for an educational event at the Harvard Museum of Natural History.
